bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 28, 1906

div1.p: Gorgas seeks advice on candidates for the Chief of Laboratory. He reports on the state of disease in Panama, noting a small pox outbreak and the absence of yellow fever since May.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 28, 1906
div1.opener:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
_______
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, C. Z.
July 28, 1906.
Maj. Jefferson R. Kean, U.S.A.,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Kean:-
div1.p:
The man to whom the Commission offered the
position of Chief of Laboratory, has declined. Is there
anybody in our Corps whom the Surgeon General thinks
suitable for the position, and he would care to have take
it? The salary would be $4000. Craig has been mentioned
in this connection. I am writing to Vaughn, Welsh, Novy,
Councilman and Flexner on the subject.

Everything doing well. Have had a little
outbreak of small pox that has rather stirred the
community up but I think we have about cleaned it out.
No yellow fever since the case reported in May.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, W. C. Gorgas.
Chief Sanitary Officer. H
